Some interesting history that you didn't cover here is that the Space Shuttle orbiters were originally supposed to have a LES of their own and that design was kept well up until when the vehicle was to go into production, but like other features it was dropped to save weight, complexity, and most importantly money. The system was referred to as the Abort Solid Rocket Motors or ASRM. It could be described as a pusher-type since it was comprised of twin rockets attached to the sides of the orbiter's aft fuselage and when fired would carry the orbiter away from a malfunctioning stack.

The ASRM's weight was initially considered acceptable since when the Shuttle reached a point where it was no longer usable, it could be fired off, the thrust boosting the stack and countering the dead weight, then jettisoned. So what's the big deal? Aside from cost there was another problem that kept rearing its ugly head; an abort scenario where the ASRM was used invoked heavy stresses on the orbiter airframe and so to keep the vehicle from breaking apart due to the aerodynamic load, the frame had to be beefed up structurally to the tune of a whopping 9 metric tons! In addition, this would not save the orbiter or its crew and payload in the advent of an exploding SSME, so its usefulness was limited to failures of the ET or SRBs.

Since NASA was under a great deal of pressure to make the Shuttle meet the DoD, CIA, and NRO's payload requirement of 65,000 lbs (29 tons) to LEO, and with costs for the program rising, ASRM was deleted from the design.

Skip over two decades later and the design of the HL-20 lifting body that was the inspiration for SNC's Dream Chaser was also going to use a pusher type abort system. However this was a separate system not directly integrated into the craft and was a part of the cone-shaped launch vehicle adapter. The crewed variant of Dream Chaser, HL-20's successor, uses an integrated pusher system that also doubles as the orbital maneuvering system. Cargo Dream Chaser could in theory use this, but being stuck under a fairing makes its use impossible.

Another reason for the pusher configuration of the LAS over the tower rockets is that an aeroshield would be required for use with a tower mounted system. Keep in mind at least one of these vehicles was designed with future space tourism aspirations in mind. An aeroshield ruins the view.

The thing is Apollo et al were Disposable.  So, it made sense that the LES could be dropped as soon as it wasn't needed, there's no reason to carry that to orbit, and back.  Sticking it on the nose, where it can easily be ditched even helped aerodynamically as it broke the sound barrier on launch.  Dragon (For example) is re-usable.  In fact, the plan was to use the LES as landing rockets after it came back.  So, the Abort rockets are also re-usable, and therefore, it makes just as much sense to integrate them into the airframe.  So they can come back with the airframe, and be re-used.  That's the main reason why the Abort Rocket was on a tower-up front:  So they could ditch it, without separating the crew cabin from the support module.

I think there is another additional reason to prefer liquid propellant engines. They save fuel.

During launch, the rocket moves in dense layers of the atmosphere at high speed. And the large 'mast' on the nose of the rocket creates a large deflecting moment of force. Also, the center of aerodynamic drag is shifted a few meters to the nose, and the center of mass remains almost in the same place.

To compensate for the deflection moment, fuel is inevitably consumed, which is included in the launch cost, and also determines the maximum weight of the spacecraft put into orbit.

the soyuz's launch abort system consists of 3 parts, the tower, the shell, and the decent capsule itself.

the shell and tower use solid rocket boosters.

ever since oh idk the late 60's the soyuz decent capsule has had liquid fueled attitude control thrusters on the decent module. which can also be used during the launch abort sequence. redundancy, if the solid fuel rockets on the outer shell don't work. in which case the shell would use its grid fins to steer, while the capsule preforms the abort burn.

this ofcourse would only happen if the abort is initiated after the abort tower is already jettisoned.

but by all means limit yourself to 1 system, i cant see that going wrong at all.

the vector thruster system has been around for a long time that used flame thrust. the US Military under DARPA tried to make upgraded kill vehicles to intercept ICBMs. calling them MKVs or Multi-kill vehicles. to target multiple ICBMs under one launch with multiple MKVs.

Propulsive landing might be developed as a backup to the parachute. As an emergency backup method it might get away with less certification. Only used in the event the chute fails so the chute is the certified abort method. An experimental backup is just a kind of bonus option that might be able to remain unproven. Eventually at some point in the future it may get developed and tested enough to be certified. I would still want a parachute primary though, less that can go wrong.

Propulsive landing might also be used in combination with a parachute if the vertical rate of descent is too fast or an unplanned landing on the wrong type of surface, such as land instead of water. In that case it could fire just for the last few seconds before landing.

Some interesting history that you didn't cover here is that the Space Shuttle orbiters were originally supposed to have a LES of their own and that design was kept well up until when the vehicle was to go into production, but like other features it was dropped to save weight, complexity, and most importantly money. The system was referred to as the Abort Solid Rocket Motors or ASRM. It could be described as a pusher-type since it was comprised of twin rockets attached to the sides of the orbiter's aft fuselage and when fired would carry the orbiter away from a malfunctioning stack.

The ASRM's weight was initially considered acceptable since when the Shuttle reached a point where it was no longer usable, it could be fired off, the thrust boosting the stack and countering the dead weight, then jettisoned. So what's the big deal? Aside from cost there was another problem that kept rearing its ugly head; an abort scenario where the ASRM was used invoked heavy stresses on the orbiter airframe and so to keep the vehicle from breaking apart due to the aerodynamic load, the frame had to be beefed up structurally to the tune of a whopping 9 metric tons! In addition, this would not save the orbiter or its crew and payload in the advent of an exploding SSME, so its usefulness was limited to failures of the ET or SRBs.

Since NASA was under a great deal of pressure to make the Shuttle meet the DoD, CIA, and NRO's payload requirement of 65,000 lbs (29 tons) to LEO, and with costs for the program rising, ASRM was deleted from the design.

Skip over two decades later and the design of the HL-20 lifting body that was the inspiration for SNC's Dream Chaser was also going to use a pusher type abort system. However this was a separate system not directly integrated into the craft and was a part of the cone-shaped launch vehicle adapter. The crewed variant of Dream Chaser, HL-20's successor, uses an integrated pusher system that also doubles as the orbital maneuvering system. Cargo Dream Chaser could in theory use this, but being stuck under a fairing makes its use impossible.

The NASA tower system of the 60's was not used to save astronauts but could have if needed. It was tested many times on vehicles specifically designed to test it: Little Joe for Mercury, and Little Joe II for Apollo. In fact one test of a Little Joe II, which destroyed itself in flight by over rotating, launched the abort tower system as it should have. Bottom line, use a tried and true system that has been tested. Hopefully it will never see use; but the very last thing you want to employ is a system that is supposed to save lives, destroy lives!!

There wasn't a problem with the tower, and I sure as hell wouldn't want some slow underpowered launch abort system like Dragon's or Starliner's if I was above an exploding rocket. 5-6 G max with 120,000 lbf thrust in just under a second vs 500,000 lbf in 0.125 seconds with a max of 10G

Why not have a launch-abort tower with a ladder construction that was very strong in tension (to carry the weight of the capsule) during an actual abort emergency yet was easily compressible (like a car's crumple zone)? Do this for a non-destructive descent and landing, in combination with descent parachutes for the tower rocket body.

Thus the tower's ladder alone would be destroyed on landing (the rest should be reusable) and you would still have the most effective (in terms of safety) abort system, providing the escape tower is separated prior to the end of its burn (so it's far away from the capsule before the capsule's own descent parachutes are deployed)! Hell, if some towers are damaged and cannot be reused, it is hardly a catastrophic loss, unlike the potential risk of having a system that prioritises re-use of components over astronauts' lives!

This is a simple lack of imagination! Whereas putting liquid fuelled, non-ejectable escape rockets within the body of the capsule quite literally turns it into a manned bomb!! No matter what levels of safety you try to build in, a significant failure will result in the catastrophic loss of life!

Using throttling of the pusher motors for attitude control is less fault tolerant than the Orion LAS concept that completely separates rotational from translational thrust with different motors.  Loss of a pintle valve or two in the LAS will not significantly affect translational thrust, and the purpose of the system is to get the crew as far away as possible from whatever is happening.  The longer moment arms of the pushers relative to the cg while using them for translational and rotational control at the same time makes loss of a thruster very close to a loss-of-crew event.  How much of the decision to forego a tower design was really a desire to minimize separation events and how much was due to hard and fast weight limits?

That solid fuel abort rocket on the New Sheppard capsule really does intrude into the capsule space. Not having it could give a much bigger space to do free-fall bouncing around the cabin in, or you could put a seat in that space for the Blue Origin crew member who babysits the tourists each flight, freeing up a window seat for someone who is paying.


I can think of ways in principle to avoid it: you could have a whole bunch of much smaller rockets, built into the floor. You could have a single pancake shaped rocket built into the floor. However it is not clear that these are feasible to engineer. I expect Blue Origin's engineers explored such options and rejected them with good reason. (The pancake shaped rocket in particular requires the exhaust gasses to turn a 90 degree angle to exit through the nozzle, so probably requires much higher chamber pressure to generate the same thrust, and possibly doesn't ramp up to full thrust so quickly.)

You forget to mention that there are projects and research studies to use methane or hydrogen (plus ox of course) to replace hypergolics in control thrusters or escape systems with laser to instant ignition with a probability higher than 99.98% in few milliseconds, the laser consume very low power. So as you can see is totally reliable to use normal fuels which are not poison, with higher isp which they can even use the main fuel tanks (for example the first stage instead compressed nitrogen thrusters).
This is something that people need to start to talk about, because the fear to "new technology" usually cause more issues than applying new technology.

There is no engineering rationale mentioned here. 1) To get low ignition latency, the fuel and oxidizer tank pressures for the SpaceX capsule have to be extremely high - around 2000 PSI. It's likely one of them exploded in the recent test. 2) A classic tree-mounted solid rocket can be fitted with canards, as on Apollo, that control the abort mode depending on where in the sequence the abort takes place. There is no complex gimbaling of motors or adjustments of thrust required. 3) No matter how careful you are, deadly remnants from often-used hypergolic fuel will be present, particularly if the shambolic thing survives more than a few rounds (I doubt it will). Let's face it - the SpaceX design is coming straight from the addled mind of Phony Stark aka Elon Musk, who knows nothing about engineering. For comparison the hypergolic tank pressures on the Apollo LM descent stage was around 250 PSI.

Solid Rocket motors can also be set off by sparks, which was a problem on one rocket (I think Apollo 1), when the rocket failed to launch, and there was no tower to evacuate the crew. There was a lot of concern a fire on the capsule could set of the solid rocket booster and kill every one on board. I would have to look up the video I recently watched on escape systems to get the details and fact check what I just said, but this was during initial development stage of abort systems, and it was one case where the escapes system become the danger due to a sensors system failure (those wires you mentioned on Apollo 1).

On Blue Origin: another reason their system makes sense is because they don't have to haul dead weight. A traditional rocket ditches the escape system once the booster separates because there's no need to carry it along for the rest of the trip. New Shepard doesn't go into orbit so it doesn't really care about hauling the extra mass around. By the time the system is no longer necessary, the vehicle has stopped thrusting anyway.
